ethnologue_comment.comment:
A major confusion in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 is with the languages called Karipuna. In addition to Karipuna Creole French [kmv] (an entry which is correct), there are two entries, both classified as Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI:

| p{4cm}} | Karipúna [kgm] | Karipuna [kuq] |
| Region: | Amapá, on French Guiana border | Rondônia, Acre, banks of Jaru, Jamery, Urupa, Cabecciras, Candeias, and Jaciparana rivers. |
| Classification: | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI |
| Alternate names: | Karipúna do Amapá, Karipúna do Uaçá | Caripuna, Jau-Navo, Juanauo, Kagwahiva, Karipuná de Rondônia, Karipuná do Guaporé |
| Population: | Extinct. | 14 (2004 ISA). |
| Language use: | Shifted to Karipúna Creole French [kmv]. | Some may also use Tenharim [pah] |


Early references to the Karipuna (or similar names) of Amapá refer to a variety of Palikúr [plu]
(**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62). The language of the Karipuna of Amapá in this sense is attested with a short wordlist,
and is indeed a Palikúr [plu] variety (**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**).
More recent references to the Karipuna of Amapá refer to an immigrant group whose original language is not attested, but, is reported to have been Nheengatu [yrl] (**hh:e:Arnaud:Uaca**,
**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62).  Except for the classification and the fact that Nheengatu [yrl] already has an entry,
the Karipúna [kgm] entry is consistent with referring to the more recent Karipuna of Amapá. Thus, whatever it refers to, the same language already has a different E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entry, either Palikur [plu]
or Nheengatu [yrl].

Until the 1950s (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:40-45, 199-213) the only language called Karipuna in the Madeira-Guaporé region was a Panoan language also known as Jau-Navo, amply attested in wordlists
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**, **hh:hv:deCrequi-MontfortRivet:Pano**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:w:Hanke:Karipuna**). However,
the name started to be applied to groups of hostile indians at the Mutumparaná and Jaciparaná which were contacted in the 1950-1970s
(**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**:104) and turned out to speak a Tupi-Guarani language of Subgroup VI
(**hh:hv:Mello:Tupi-Guarani:2000**, **hh:w:Monserrat:Amondawa**, **hh:w:Betts:Kagwahiva**),
which we may call Kawahib. FUNAI frivolously used the name Karipuna for this Kawahib group (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:45), encouraging the confusion we now observe. The Karipuna [kuq] entry mixes information from the Panoan Karipuna (e.g., the name Jau-Navo) and the Kawahib Karipuna (e.g., the classification). The Panoan Karipuna is otherwise missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 whereas the Kawahib Karipuna speak the same language as the language of several other entries. See also: Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah].

Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Morerebi [xmo], Paranawát [paf], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Wiraféd [wir].

meds: Vezzaro, Antônia de Fátima Galdino da Silva 2015
Antônia de Fátima Galdino da Silva Vezzaro 2014

ethnologue_comment.comment: The extinct Potiguára [pog] of northeastern Brazil is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate language, but there is no attestion of the language of this group to the effect that it is different from all other languages in the region. If anything, data potentially attributable to Potiguára in the Dutch National Archives render it a variety of Tupinambá [tpn] (p.c. Willem Adelaar 2011). See also: Tupinambá [tpn].

Tupinikin [tpk] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate entry, but, in fact, only three words are attested (**hh:ew:Garcia:Mirandela**) which is insufficient grounds for separating it from the other entries of Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup III
(**hh:hv:Loukotka:SAmerica**:103-105).

ethnologue_comment.comment: Krahô [xra] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate Eastern Timbira language, but the language spoken by the Krahô is intelligible with that of the Canela [ram] entry (**hh:typ:Miranda:Kraho**:12, **hh:s:PopjesPopjes:Canela-Kraho**, **hh:e:Nimuendaju:Timbira**:26). See also: Canela-Krahô [ram].

Krikati-Timbira [xri] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate Eastern Timbira language but already **hh:e:Nimuendaju:Timbira**:17 declared that ``The Krĩkatí dialect completely coincides with that of the Pukóbye'', where Pukóbye belongs to the Pará Gavião [gvp] entry. See also: Pará Gavião [gvp].

ethnologue_comment.comment: Macuni, an extinct Western Maxakali language attested with a wordlist in **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24.
Capoxo, an extinct Western Maxakali language attested with a wordlist in **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24.
Masacará, an extinct Brazilian Kamakanan language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hvw:Silva:Kamaka**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**).
Cotoxó, an extinct Brazilian Kamakanan language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hvw:Silva:Kamaka**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:Kamakan**).
Menien, an extinct Brazilian Kamakanan language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hvw:Silva:Kamaka**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:ew:Metraux:Kamakan**).

Coroado-Puri, an extinct language of Brazil related to Puri [prr], is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:hvw:Loukotka:Coroado**, **hh:hvw:daNeto:Puri**). See also: Puri [prr].

Cashinawa of the Tarauacá river, an extinct Panoan language in the Pano Nawa subgroup, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hvw:RivetTastevin:Pano**, **hh:hvb:Fleck:Panoan**). It is not be confused with the more well-known Kashinawa of the Ibuaçu River which is covered in the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 Cashinahua [cbs] entry. See also: Cashinahua [cbs].

Careful analysis of early vocabularies of languages surfacing under the name Remo (**hh:hvb:Fleck:Panoan**) necessitate distinguishing another two extinct languages Remo of the Blanco river (**hh:w:Leuque:Remo**) and Remo of the Jaquirana river (**hh:hw:Braulino:Fronteira**, **hh:w:Carvalho:Remo**) missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24, in addition to the extant Remo (of the Moa river) [rem] entry (**hh:w:Loos:Remo-Moa**). The three are closely related but fall into the Pano Nawa subfamily with different languages between them (**hh:hvb:Fleck:Panoan**). See also: Remo of the Moa river [rem].

(**hh:hw:deCastelnau:Amerique:V**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**), Mayoruna of the Jandiatuba river (**hh:w:deAlviano:Maiorunas**), Mayoruna of the Tabatinga river (**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**), in addition to the extant Matsés-Mayoruna [mcf] entry. iso_retirement.name: Papavô
iso_retirement.remedy: Any usage probably referred to one of: Amarakaeri [amr], Huachipaeri [hug], Kulina [cul], Amahuaca [amc], or Yawanawa [ywn]
iso_retirement.comment:
This is a name that was used to refer to a group of several different
uncontacted groups. It is no longer used to refer to this group because it is
now known that there are four separate, now identified groups that fell under
this label (see http://lucy.ukc.ac.uk/Sonja/RF/Ukpr/Report34.htm).

These groups are: Harakmbet--two languages, Amarakaeri [amr] and Huachipaeri
[hug]; Kulina [cul]; Amahuaca [amc]; and Yawanawa [ywn]

ethnologue_comment.comment: E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 has an entry for Pisabo [pig]. But Pisabo is unattested (**hh:hvb:Fleck:Panoan**) and cannot be asserted to have been a separate language.

Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Paranawát [paf], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz], Wiraféd [wir].

E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 has an entry for Tukumanféd [tkf]. It is a presumed Kawahib language earlier spoken on the middle Machado River, but is unattested (**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**:24, **hh:hv:Loukotka:SAmerica**:115) and cannot be asserted to have been different from other Kawahib languages.

ethnologue_comment.comment: The southern Arawakan Guana (Brazil) [gqn] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate language. But the examination by **hh:v:deCarvalho:Terena** shows that it can be subsumed as Tereno [ter] on purely linguistic grounds. See also: Terena-Kinikinao-Chane [ter].

meds: Willem F.H. Adelaar and Hélène B. Brijnen 2014

ethnologue_comment.comment: Guinau, an extinct Arawakan language (**hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak**), is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:w:Schomburgk:Guinau**, **hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Guinau**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**). It has been shown by **hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak-Enciclopedia**:583-600 to be an independent language of the Medio Rio Negro subgroup.

Aruan, an extinct Northern Maipuran language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:w:Nimuendaju:Arua**, **hh:w:Ferreira:Aruans**). It has been shown by **hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak-Enciclopedia**:539-574 to be an independent language of the Negro-Roraima group.

meds: Willem F.H. Adelaar and Hélène B. Brijnen 2014

ethnologue_comment.comment: Manao, an extinct Northern Arawakan language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:e:Metraux:Manao**, **hh:w:deGoeje:Manao**, **hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak**, **hh:t:Joyce:Manaos**). It has been shown by **hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak-Enciclopedia**:539-574 to be an independent language of the Negro-Roraima group.

Cariay, an extinct Northern Arawakan (**hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak**) language attested with a wordlist in **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. It has been shown by **hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak-Enciclopedia**:539-574 to be an independent language of the Negro-Roraima group.

ethnologue_comment.comment: Sikiana [sik] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate Cariban language and there is a matching ethnic group with this name (**hh:h:Carlin:Cariban-Suriname**) but their language is ``a very close dialect'' of Kaxuiâna [kbb] (**hh:g:Meira:Tiriyo**:5, **hh:hv:Frikel:Nord-Para**:558). See also: Kaxuiâna [kbb].

A major confusion in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 is with the languages called Karipuna. In addition to Karipuna Creole French [kmv] (an entry which is correct), there are two entries, both classified as Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI:

| p{4cm}} | Karipúna [kgm] | Karipuna [kuq] |
| Region: | Amapá, on French Guiana border | Rondônia, Acre, banks of Jaru, Jamery, Urupa, Cabecciras, Candeias, and Jaciparana rivers. |
| Classification: | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI |
| Alternate names: | Karipúna do Amapá, Karipúna do Uaçá | Caripuna, Jau-Navo, Juanauo, Kagwahiva, Karipuná de Rondônia, Karipuná do Guaporé |
| Population: | Extinct. | 14 (2004 ISA). |
| Language use: | Shifted to Karipúna Creole French [kmv]. | Some may also use Tenharim [pah] |


Early references to the Karipuna (or similar names) of Amapá refer to a variety of Palikúr [plu]
(**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62). The language of the Karipuna of Amapá in this sense is attested with a short wordlist,
and is indeed a Palikúr [plu] variety (**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**).
More recent references to the Karipuna of Amapá refer to an immigrant group whose original language is not attested, but, is reported to have been Nheengatu [yrl] (**hh:e:Arnaud:Uaca**,
**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62).  Except for the classification and the fact that Nheengatu [yrl] already has an entry,
the Karipúna [kgm] entry is consistent with referring to the more recent Karipuna of Amapá. Thus, whatever it refers to, the same language already has a different E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entry, either Palikur [plu]
or Nheengatu [yrl].

Until the 1950s (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:40-45, 199-213) the only language called Karipuna in the Madeira-Guaporé region was a Panoan language also known as Jau-Navo, amply attested in wordlists
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**, **hh:hv:deCrequi-MontfortRivet:Pano**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:w:Hanke:Karipuna**). However,
the name started to be applied to groups of hostile indians at the Mutumparaná and Jaciparaná which were contacted in the 1950-1970s
(**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**:104) and turned out to speak a Tupi-Guarani language of Subgroup VI
(**hh:hv:Mello:Tupi-Guarani:2000**, **hh:w:Monserrat:Amondawa**, **hh:w:Betts:Kagwahiva**),
which we may call Kawahib. FUNAI frivolously used the name Karipuna for this Kawahib group (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:45), encouraging the confusion we now observe. The Karipuna [kuq] entry mixes information from the Panoan Karipuna (e.g., the name Jau-Navo) and the Kawahib Karipuna (e.g., the classification). The Panoan Karipuna is otherwise missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 whereas the Kawahib Karipuna speak the same language as the language of several other entries. See also: Karipúna Creole French [kmv], Karipúna [kuq], Nhengatu [yrl], Palikúr [plu], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah].

Salumá [slj] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate Cariban language,
but the only two wordlists pertaining to a Cariban language with this name in the stated area is clearly Trio [tri]
(**hh:g:Carlin:Trio**:8). If Salumá is to be understood to refer to the group **hh:hv:Frikel:Nord-Para** calls Charúma, then their language is that in the Waiwai [waw] entry. Either way, no separate Cariban language Salumá [slj] can be asserted. See also: Trió [tri], Waiwai [waw].

E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 lists two languages Kanamari [knm] and Katukina
[kav] as per the below.

| name | Kanamarí |
| Population | 1,330 (Moore 2006). 100 Tsohom-Djapa speakers (Crevels 2007) |
|  | Ethnic population: 2,750 (2006 FUNASA). |
| Location | Amazonas, upper regions of Jurua, Jutai, Itaquai rivers. |
| Language Use | Vigorous. |
| Language Status | 6a (Vigorous). |
| Language Maps | Western Central Brazil |
| ISO 639-3 | knm |
| Dialects | Tshom-Djapa (Txunhuã Dyapá, Txunhuã-Djapá), Tsohon-Djapa. |
| Country | Brazil |
| Classification | Maipurean, Southern, Southern Outlier, Piro |
| Alternate Names | Canamarí, Kanamaré |


| name | Katukína |
| Population | No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 590 (2008 FUNASA). |
| Other Comments | Different from Panoan Katukína [knt] in Amazonas and Acre. |
| Location | Acre. |
| Language Status | 9 (Dormant). |
| ISO 639-3 | kav |
| Dialects | Cutiadapa (Kutia-Dyapa). |
| Country | Brazil |
| Classification | Katukinan |
| Alternate Names | Catuquina, Katukina do Jutaí, Katukina do Rio Biá, Pidá-Djapá |


The language matching the name, location, population and dialect information of the Kanamari [knm] entry, is well-known from the linguistic (e.g.,
**hh:s:QueixalosdosAnjos:Katukina-Kanamari**, **hh:typ:Queixalos:Katukina**, **hh:s:Groth:Canamari**, **hh:phon:deMagalhaes:Kanamari**, **hh:hsoc:AnonbyHolbrook:Javari**, **hh:ew:Carvalho:Javari-Itacoai-Jurua**)
and ethnographic (e.g., **hh:he:Melatti:Javari**, **hh:he:Verneau:Amazon**)
literature. But this language is not, as the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 classification has it, a Maipurean Arawakan language closest to Piro (Yine)
[yib]. The idea that it is closely related to Piro ultimately stems from a name confusion with the Canamaré vocabulary in
**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**. This Canamaré vocabulary is indeed so close to Piro as to count as Piro, but it is not the same language the Kanamari indicated by the data in the Kanamari [knm] entry, as shown already by **hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**. Turning now to the Katukina
[kav]-entry, its location, classification, alternative names and dialect names (but not speaker number) corresponds to the Katukina known in the literature (e.g.,
**hh:phon:dosAnjos:Katukina**). However, this Katukina [kav]
language is mutually intelligible with Kanamari [knm]
(**hh:g:dosAnjos:Katukina-Kanamari**:8-16) and the two should count uncontroversially as one entry.  Older vocabularies are also similar enough to count as the same language
(**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**) so there is no reason to posit a separate entry for a Katukina that existed in the past. Thus,
one of the Kanamari [knm] and Katukina [kav] entries is spurious. The confusion in this case may have been licensed by the existence of yet more distinct languages surfacing under the name Katukina, i.e., the Panoan Katukina (**hh:hwsoc:deAguiar:Katukina**) and the problematic Catuquinarú vocabulary (**hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**). See also: Katukína-Kanamarí [knm].

E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 has an entry for Pokangá [pok] as an Eastern Tucanoan language of the Upper Tiquié river in northwest Brazil. The entry contains the comment that ``The people claim to speak Waimaha
(Northern Barasano) [bao]''.  The Waimaha [bao] entry indeed has the Upper Tiquié river included in the list of locations. This area has been survey many times and there is no other Tucano language spoken there
(**hh:e:Jackson:Fish-People**, **hh:es:Giacone:Tucanos**, **hh:hw:Koch-Grunberg:Betoya**)
except Tucano [tuo] and Waimaha [bao] (also known as Bará), and the non-Tucano languages of the hunting-gathering peoples living between the larger rivers also have entries. The Pokangá [pok] entry is spurious, and should be merged with the Waimaha [bao] entry as the information in both already indicates. See also: Tucano [tuo], Waimaha [bao].

Tingui-Boto [tgv] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as an unclassified language of Brazil. There is certainly a corresponding ethnic group, but this group speaks Portuguese. They retain some of their ancestral language for ritual purposes, but this language is Dzubukuá (According to Vera Lúcia Calheiros Mata
<http: pib.socioambiental.org='' pt='' povo='' tingui-boto='' 1050=''>
accessed 7 February 2012.). Dzubukuá
(**hh:g:deQueiroz:Dzubukua**) is subsumed under the (otherwise highly problematic) Kariri-Xoco [kzw] entry.


See also: Karirí-Xocó [kzw], South Ucayali Ashéninka [cpy].

meds: Dantas, Beatriz G. and José Augusto L. Sampaio and Maria Rosário G. de Carvalho 1998

ethnologue_comment.comment: E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 has an entry for Kapinawá [xpn]. But Kapinawá is unattested (**hh:e:Sampaio:Kapinawa**) and cannot be asserted to have been a separate language.

ethnologue_comment.comment:
Ethnologue (editions 16-19) has two entries Karirí-Xocó [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo],
with the following information:

| p{5cm} p{5cm}} | Karirí-Xocó [kzw] | Xukurú [xoo] |
| Dialects: | Kipeá (Quipea), Kamurú (Camuru), Dzubukuá (Dzubucua), Sabujá (Pedra Branca). Other dialects or languages are even less well attested. |  |
| Region: | Alagoas. | Pernambuco, Serra de Urubá (Arobá) near Cimbres City, Bahía. |
| Classification: | Unclassified | Unclassified |
| Language development: | Grammar. |  |
| country: | Brazil | Brazil |
| Alternate names: | Karirí, Kariri Xucó, Kipeá, Xocó, Xokó, Xokó-Karirí, Xukurú, Xukuru Kariri | Kirirí, Kirirí-Xokó |
| Population: | No known speakers. Ethnic population: 1,062 (1995 SIL). | No known speakers. Ethnic population: 6,363. |
| Language use: | Shifted to Portuguese. | Shifted to Portuguese. |


The are (at least) three attested languages relevant for these two entries. The first, which we may call Kipeá-Dzubukuá, is a dialect complex consisting of Dzubukuá, Kipeá, Kamurú (Camuru), Sabujá
for which Jesuits grammars/catechisms are the main source of documentation. Quite a lot is known about Kipeá-Dzubukuá grammar,
i.e., noun classes, VSO constituent order, ergativity and so on
(**hh:s:Mamiani:Kiriri**, **hh:s:Azevedo:Kiriri**, **hh:hvs:Adam:Kariri**, **hh:typ:Larsen:Kiriri**, **hh:hv:Rodrigues:Macro-Je**, **hh:typ:Rodrigues:Kariri**, **hh:t:deNantes:Kariris**, **hh:phonw:deQuieroz:Dzubukua**). The second, which we may call Chocó, is attested only in a few minuscule wordlists
(**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hv:PompeuSobrinho:Tapuias-NE**, **hh:ld:Pompeu:Tapuias**).
The third, which we may call Shucurú, is attested only in a few wordlists
(**hh:hvw:Loukotka:Inconnues**, **hh:w:Lapenda:Xucuru**, **hh:hw:Meader:Nordeste**).
Whatever the meagre data of Chocó and Shukurú tell us, it does not support any constellation of Chocó, Shukurú or Kipeá-Dzubukuá
being the same language or the same family
(**hh:hv:Loukotka:Non-Tupi-NEBresil**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:SAmerica**). The Chocó lived in Alagoas when first mentioned in the literature,
whereas no variety of Kipeá-Dzubukuá or Shucurú is attested in Alagoas before the 20th century
(**hh:e:Hohenthal:Shucuru**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:Non-Tupi-NEBresil**, **hh:h:Nimuendaju:Etno-Historico**). The descendants of Chocó, Shucurú, Kipeá-Dzubukuá (and other tribes) were subsequently missionized together in various places and constellations, to the end that, at present, they could be considered one group from an ethnographic perspective
(**hh:e:Carneiro:Kariri-Shoco**) who speak only Portuguese and with Alagoas as one of its locations. However, E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries are supposed to reflect languages rather than ethnicities, so the information in the Karirí-Xocó [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo] entries are, at best,
anachronistic. Ideally, a new entry should be created for Chocó (it was probably extinct by 1951, but, except for rememberers, all three were probably extinct by 1951), and the names and locations of the Kipeá-Dzubukuá [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo] entries should be changed to reflect the names and locations of the (past) speakers of the language of the entry, rather than the names and locations used for descendants who do not speak the language of the entry. See also: Karirí-Xocó [kzw], Xukurú [xoo].

meds: Edward Koehn and Sally Sharp Koehn 1971
Jules Crevaux and P. Sagot and Adam, Lucien 1882

ethnologue_comment.comment: Palmela, an extinct displaced Cariban once spoken in Rondônia, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:w:daFonseca:Redor:II:1881**, **hh:w:Becker-Donner:Guapore**, **hh:hew:Nordenskiold:Forskningar**).

meds: de la Salle de l'Estaing, M. 1763

ethnologue_comment.comment: Wayumara, an extinct Guianan Cariban language most closely related to Maquiritare [mch], is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hew:Farabee:Central-Caribs**, **hh:hv:Girard:Carib**, **hh:hw:Schomburgk:Eighteen-Guiana**, **hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Sapara-Purukoto-Wayumara**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**). See also: Ye'kwana [mch].

meds: Jules Crevaux and P. Sagot and Adam, Lucien 1882

ethnologue_comment.comment: Pimenteira, an extinct Kuikuroan Cariban language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:Non-Tupi-NEBresil**).

Bonari, an extinct Cariban language most closely related to Waimiri-Atroari [atr], is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:w:deSousa:Bonaris**, **hh:hv:Girard:Carib**). See also: Waimiri-Atroari [atr].
Pauxiana, a presumed extinct Venezuelan Cariban language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:ew:Meyer:Pauxiana**, **hh:h:dAlmada:Rio-Branco**, **hh:ew:Salathe:Karime**).
Paravilhana, an extinct Venezuelan Cariban language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:h:dAlmada:Rio-Branco**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:hv:Adam:Caribe**).

Sapara, a presumed extinct Venezuelan Cariban language, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:h:dAlmada:Rio-Branco**, **hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Sapara-Purukoto-Wayumara**, **hh:hv:Girard:Carib**).

meds: Hawkins, W. Neil and Robert E. Hawkins 1953

ethnologue_comment.comment:
Apiaka of the Tocantins river, an extinct Cariban language of the Xingú subgroup attested with wordlists in **hh:w:Ehrenreich:Apiaka**, **hh:w:Krause:Yaruma**, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24.
It is not to be confused with the more well-known Apiaká [api] language of the Tapajos river in Tupi-Guarani Subgroup VI. See also: Apiaká [api].

Yarumá, a Cariban language of the Xingu subgroup, is missing
(**hh:e:Levi-Strauss:UXingu**, **hh:ew:GalvaoSimoes:Txikao**). Yaruma is listed as a dialect of Suyá [suy] (a Jê language), presumably because the ethnic group assimilated to the Suyá (**hh:he:VillasBoas:Xingu**),
but the original Yarumá, which is attested
(**hh:ew:GalvaoSimoes:Txikao**), is certainly not a Suyá dialect. See also: Suyá [suy].

meds: Eduardo Galvão and Mário F. Simões 1965
Eduardo Galvão and Mário F. Simões 1965
